Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: The Math Simulator - Where Data Input is Directly Linked to Functional Output
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project is designed to address the dramatic drop in US student proficiency happening in the middle school grades. Seen across years of international test data, this drop highlights the urgent need to prepare students for success in the math classroom. Without a solid foundation in math, US students cannot succeed in science, technology and engineering. They will be less likely to graduate high school, will struggle to succeed in college, and are at risk of being left behind in a global economy. Many look to technology to address this challenge - but the 22 million US students struggling in mathematics do not need yet another virtual tutorial, online lecture or more practice time on a computer doing textbook-based math problems. What they need is a simulator. A comprehensive simulator where they can see, hear and experience just how math works - and why it matters. This project would develop an innovative product that delivers interactive video challenge math problems, aligned to Common Core State Standards for 5th through 8th grade mathematics, into any classroom.

This product will use a complex programming system and codebase to allow teachers to collect student data and responses to complex math problems that result in functional output, accepting rapid real-time responses from multiple student devices, that can range from computers to mobile phones, in a low-bandwidth environment. Within the product, teachers generate tasks and challenges for students; students would grapple with multi-step problems and provide answers, with the teacher maintaining ultimate control over what is shared out with the classroom as a whole when the simulation is played out. Student data and responses are captured and are connected directly to a robust learning management system. The product is anticipated to be highly effective by providing students with an opportunity for Productive Failure (PF) prior to instruction; PF shows a higher effect size for both conceptual learning and transfer to novel situations than typical approaches where instruction is provided first. The Phase I project will conduct preliminary research using an experimental design to determine effect size of student growth from use of the intervention on a single CCSS standard.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Math Simulator is designed to address all 146 Common Core State Standards (CCSS) for math, grades 5th to 8th, through engaging, “virtual reality” story problems deployed by teachers and solved by students. However, unlike a traditional story problem or online game, students see and experience how their solution is working out, receiving real-time feedback and motivation to continue grappling with the problem until it is successfully solved.

When fully completed, a teacher can launch The Math Simulator, in front of the class, and send students into a rich adventure story where they encounter a challenge that must be overcome. The challenge is a math problem that aligns exactly to the specific standard the teacher wants to work on that day; but for students, what matters is that they have an authentic problem in front of them, a problem they want to solve. Each student inputs a solution on his or her device, which is transmitted to the main system. Together, they watch the outcomes of their solutions, both the successes and the failures. They try again. Math takes on meaning, and students can try again and see the direct results of their mathematical abilities.

Research was conducted with over 700 students (500 more students than the original study design) in four schools with stringent, randomized controlled study designs. Initial results indicate that students using The Math Simulator showed statistically significant greater gains than the two groups using products currently on the market. Learning gains were retained longer in the MSM group. Additionally, achievement gains were significant on both of the simulations developed and tested, with large pre-test, post-test effect sizes, indicating that the fundamental structure warrants further study. The Math Simulator interface showed a higher degree of ease of use and higher engagement in the classroom, compared to other curricula, and performed technically as expected. Finally, a further area of research was commenced to determine if instruction prior to, or after, Productive Failure (PF) with The Math Simulator would show achievement differences. Initial results indicate that students that received instruction after the PF showed higher scores on the post-test and the delayed post-test.
